title: 103_s1208
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were cared for by local government units before the National Park Service took over preservation responsibilities. Financial constraints have hindered the Federal Government from meeting the capital needs of these historic sites. The National Park Service's responsibilities have prevented the Federal Government from meeting the capital needs of historic sites. Minting a United States coin can help commemorate these buildings and fund their maintenance. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 1,000,000 $1 silver coins with specific specifications. The coins will depict the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, and contain inscriptions of various patriotic phrases. The coins will be legal tender and the silver for minting will come from designated stockpiles. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from designated stockpiles. The design will be chosen in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility. Minting can begin 30 days after enactment for up to 1 year. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted. A surcharge of $7 per coin is required for all sales. Procurement regulations are waived for goods and services needed for this Act. Surcharge proceeds will be distributed accordingly. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

    Surcharges collected from coin sales will be split: 50% to reduce national debt, 50% to Independence Hall Preservation Fund for park improvements.

SEC. 10. AUDITS.

    The Comptroller General can audit the Independence Hall Preservation Fund's expenditures. SEC. 11. NUMISMATIC PUBLIC ENTERPRISE FUND.

    Coins issued under this Act are subject to provisions of section 5134 of title 31, United States Code, regarding the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES.

The Secretary must ensure that issuing coins under this Act will not cost the government. Payment security is required before issuing any coin, including full payment, satisfactory security, or a guarantee from a qualified depository institution.
